messages: d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (11:39): http://www.456bereastreet.com/archive/200705/help_keep_accessibility_and_semantics_in_html/
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:41): heh
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:41): we're evil!
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (11:41): This is a call to action directed at all standardistas and accessibilitistas.
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (11:41): i was wondering when it was going to start
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:42): but I'm not sure what he's talking about though
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:43): seems like quite a misunderstanding of the WHATWG proposal
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (11:43): i assume different people will cry bloody murder for different reasons
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:43): as John Foliot said, the problem with not knowing history is that you're doomed to repeat it
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:44): (which applies equally well to John Foliot, but he didn't admit that)
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:44): (to be fair, I didn't point it out either)
d114be1698421a7cec050e2207d29631 (11:45): I suppose from the mass of emails you could take any point of view on the direction of the wg
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (11:45): not quite, keeping back compat principle holds, no matter what, i reckon.
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:46): some people think it should not hold
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:47): Roger Johansson seems to think the WG can somehow mandate browsers to implement UI that indicates errors in pages like iCab does
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:47): that doesn't make much sense to me with at least 99% non-conformance

6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (11:50): i think back-compat will hold. simply put, w3c has to do what broswer makers want. all other browser makers have to do what MS want. else, MS moves out, or all browsser makers (MS and others) move out. and this WG basically dissolves.
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:51): Well, it's part of the charter, but it's not what people argue for
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (11:52): i think what i said still holds. no MS, no WG. no broswer vendors (MS and others), no group.
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:53): WHATWG exists without MS so I'm not really convinced
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (11:53): (not that MS wasn't invited, btw)
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (11:54): whatwg might keep at it, but that is different from this WG, i think.
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (11:54): would you guys still want a w3c seal if MS leaves?
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:00): yeah, I think so
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (12:01): oh, then this WG could continue
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:02): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0: did I ever tell you about my key for translating messages from supporters of "valid markup"?
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (12:03): back-compat is hardwired into the charter, if i'm not wrong, so generic reversal of that is basically out of the question, no matter how many people complain
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:03): 6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b: the charter is actually maddeningly vague about the matter
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:03): blames the chairs for not steering enough
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (12:04): 139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884, about back-compat? for me, the deciding word is "incremental"
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:04): unless the idea is for this group to remain unproductive, that is
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (12:04): i doubt that, e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0. cause of the vision document
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:04): the other thing the charter says is that the new language should define a syntax compatible with popular browser impl
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (12:04): e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0, right
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:05): one of our chairs has done exactly 0 chairing
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:05): the other has done a moderate amount but seems to move kind of ponderously and with an excessive zeal for perfect consensus
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:05): in a day over two months now
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:06): still no outcome of the vote
69b301143beca31e76cf7bfdbd4d5537 (12:06): I wonder if the <em> vs. <i> thread is petering out?
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (12:07): if anyone asks me...you guys should not worry about votes
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:07): I'm not worrying about the outcome of the votes
6ce98a4a7b6e097946960dcb1f2d404b (12:07): at least unless outrage grows much
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:07): I'm worrying about lack of progress
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:07): not so much worrying
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:07): we've so far accomplished nothing
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:07): more being upset with
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:08): but that might change in a few days if the votes pass
e3fb62ebfa4f36acf5cbff6a6ed0f2e0 (12:10): I agree that some people seem to aim too much for perfect consensus
139513027e8e90b5582cbc68fc733884 (12:13): it's impractical to try for more consensus in a huge group than is done in most medium sized groups
